It's not that we get to know the characters very well, but the very strong cast help to lift the material and make their characters and their dire circumstances seem real.'Everest' isn't quite the film it aspires to be, but it's an ascent worth taking.

title: Everest..
content: I loved this movie, based on a true story.I wasn't a big fan of Jason Clarke until I watched this, but he did a solid job in it, some very good performances throughout, some nice shots and the scenery is great and very well directed..I went on to read 'Into thin air' by Jon Krakauer, who was one of the survivors of this fateful expedition, very good book if you want a more personal account of what happened and some nice photography in it too..

Breathtakingly beautiful and immersive as few movies have been recently and nail bitingly tense. "Everest" is one of 2015's most pleasant surprises. A thriller that doesn't overdo it's true story and makes for one of those experiences where you will be stuck on the screen for two full hours be it for the tension or just for the magnificent photography.This could have easily been a throw away film with some good imagery and maybe a couple of good moments, but actually the director cared about every aspect of the movie and with one of the most impressive casts of the year, which gives its all in an assemble of very committed and convincing performances, he made a film in which you get to know about ten or twelve characters very well, you relate and care about them, but most importantly every single one of them has a full fleshed arch, that you understand and empathize with. That is actually very, very difficult to do with so many characters. They don't obviously all have an arch worthy of a Michael Corleone, they aren't explored so deeply, but it is very remarkable to see a film treat so many characters so respectfully and balance them all out in two hours.Yet easily the most impressive part of the film is the setting and the camera work. This is one of those very, very rare movies nowadays where I actually asked myself "how the hell did they do that?". This film feels real in ways that I couldn't even have imagined going in. Really this is as impressive as it gets. I kept asking myself how did the director achieve this, he made it actually look like they were truly climbing the Everest, he made you feel there in that mountain with the characters. It was amazing. The filmmakers really had an understanding of their geography and managed to bring the audience in and never, ever loose it. The combination of this and the characters really made for an experience that will be remembered.Of course the movie has limits and I think it actually has set limits for itself. There isn't any superior storytelling or revolutionary techniques. The film knows what it is doing and does it perfectly, but it tells the story in a very conventional way. That is obviously perfectly fine, but don't excpet to come out from this film feeling your life has changed. It doesn't explore deeper themes that are only mentioned, it doesn't put a personal style on things. It also becomes very pushy with its true story material in the final note and may I say needlessly so. I really hate when movies do this. There is no absolute need to do it: shoving down your throat on the last thirty seconds an emotional punch that feels forced and unnecessary.Nevertheless, I was both moved and thrilled by the film, I really enjoyed it and had a blast in the theater, I really recommend to see this in the cinema even though I don't think it will be ever worth a rewatch.

title: Awesome Scenery, Predictable Dangers, Nothing New
content: (Flash Review)Follows the story of climbing expedition groups and the voyage to the top of Everest. It touches on character's passion for climbing, families left at home worrying, how crowded it has become on the few routes and conflicts that arise. Oh and of course the risk and danger at every step. Feel the cold and wind. Feel lungs strain for every breath. Feel the extreme drive to keep climbing. Of course getting up is only half the battle. You didn't think a Hollywood movie titled Everest would go smoothly did you? Ratchet up the drama and the weather for the dramatic decent rife with life teetering on the precipice. This has everything you'd expect, amazing mountaintop views, human struggle and will to survive and it does its best to ratchet up the emotions. It certainly achieves its objective.

title: Worth Watching 'Everest'
content: The movie was well made and the Director made full justice to the movie. I found this movie very interesting mainly due to its focus on Rob Hall who never loses hopes and acts as a supporter to his mates. The Soundtrack and the Cinematography is really astonishing.It takes a lot of courage to climb Everest and for Mountain climbers, it is a dream. The story of Rob Hall and Scott Fischer and their teamwork was very good to reach to the top. Everest is a stunning looking film tp come from, feeling totally exhausted.Overall, Everest was exactly What I wanted. Everest may have a definite chance to make it into Oscars Nominations.

title: Delivers the exact emotion atmosphere
content: I had to stop myself from bursting into tears. The emotional state of the situation that happened on 10th of May in 1996 is delivered, and leaves a profound mark in your conscience.While having some high-altitude mountaineering experience enables the viewer to get more sense of the sub-stories, just empathy and understanding that death cannot be negated will overwhelm you. This movie is not about sport, neither a guide to climbing top of the world, but a weep of sorrow, a scream of pain and unfathomable risks that climbers impose on themselves. When you start dying by just getting there, and every step you make can be your last one, what would you do in such a situation?

title: An incredible, dramatic, truthful and adventurous movie based on an incredible, "unfilmable" true story
content: Everest hits the heights quite well, thanks to successful acting performances and spectacular visual effects making the film an exciting, tense and suspenseful history drama popcorn thriller. This movie is based on a true story of the 1996 Mount Everest Disaster and dramatizes it very well. It's also partially based on the book "Into Thin Air" by Jon Krakauer, a journalist and one of the survivors. It's so intense, adventurous, thrilling and powerful thanks to brilliant direction and 3D special effects which makes this one of the best films of 2015 on my list after Jurassic World, Inside Out, Mall Cop 2 and Lazer Team. Michael Kelly does a great job portraying Jon. I think "Into Thin Air" is a long, tedious and a non film able book, similar to Yann Martel's 2001 Adventure fantasy novel "Life of Pi", yet it was transformed into a theatrical film by Director Mr. Lee, and with the help of an excellent cast, narration, changing between perspectives (haphazard flashbacks) as well as spectacular 3D visual effects, realistic green screen and computer generated imagery which made Ang's film a visual masterpiece and a faithful and delightful adaptation of Yann's book with pi's 227 day journey sure to impress the audience. Even if the movie ending is not as ambiguous as the book's, it's emotionally and spiritually insightful, beautifully coloured which amazingly portrays the book's imagery and so it overall sticks very well to the book. Same thing applies to this film. It's exciting to watch for the audience, thanks to great acting and spectacular visual effects. It's dizzying cinematography and CGI slam the heights perfectly. 10/10!!!!!

title: Stars in the snow
content: That isn't to say the Oscar bait of a cast goes completely to waste. Jason Clarke exhibits perhaps one of his best performances inside his recent string of action movies, rebounding from this summer's lackluster 'Terminator Genisys' and building upon his solidifying appearance in 'Dawn of The Planet of The Apes.' With an impeccable Kiwi accent and sincerely heart wrenching exchanges with his wife, Clarke as expatiation leader Rob Hall skillfully suffers the very fate he so desperately intended to protect from the team and himself. Applause should also be reserved to Robin Wright and Keira Knightly, whose portrayals of distressed yet strong-willed wives are especially commendable, granted that they were forced to concoct pure pain, hope, and determination without co-stars Clarke or Brolin in the room. Josh Brolin as the hard-nosed Beck Weathers is one of the film's more well rounded showings, evolving the character from subconsciously terrified yet confident climber to a frost eaten walking dead.FULL REVIEW HERE: http://indieadam.com/2015/09/20/everest-review-indieadam/

title: Thoroughly Tear Jerking...Best Film I've seen in a long time
content: This is a beautiful but harrowing film,which will have you on the edge of your seat the entire time! I felt sick with worry and cried my eyes out. The acting in the film is fantastic and really had you believing the story. I mean through the entire film it was like I was there rooting for the characters and there families. I was hiding behind a pillow one minute and screaming at the television the next! This is the sort of film that really helps to give you perspective. In my opinion the actors really make you believe that they are the people that this happened to in real life. Watch it! You will come away speechless! But in a good way! 😃

title: A stunning breathless expedition
content: I went to see the movie with high expectations because of the cast & came out with big wow in my mouth.Other than the cast the visual of the movie affected me very much.every scene is stunning,it made to feel i was in mountain because of breathless scenes.everyone acted very well didn't use any cliché bonding friendship in the end or any other dramas they stick to their role & done a fine job i knew Jake & josh they wont disappoint me but Jason Clarke proved that he is also dependable actor with his performance.This movie is in every way to deserve an Oscar.

title: Such an underrated movie.
content: I'm now watching this on Redbox for the 3rd time and I think it took me this long to truly appreciate it. For all of the "experts" tearing it down about the technical aspects, it's a movie. It always bothers me when films set in these harsh conditions have actors removing their protection to show their faces, but once again it's a movie. These are the best actors and a crew that truly suffered to bring this true story to the big screen. There is no faking dealing with those conditions in order to make a film like this. The writing is top notch. This is so much more than just about the tragedy, but what actually caused it. Introducing commerce into a world it has no business in has changed the landscape of that region and created a false sense of security for fools with more money then brains. Rob Hall was a victim of Karma. He saw an opportunity to make money over the fact that those who have no business on the mountain should not be there. I think the movie really showed all aspects in what eventually created this disaster, if you wanna call it that. All of these people were there of their own volition, a disaster would be something more like the tsunami in 2004. When I see the haters of movies like this along with so many more on the IMDb, I don't get upset I just know those people have never done anything substantial in their lives and have no idea what it takes to make something like this. This is a great, very even handed telling of an amazing story in the history of this world.

title: *Yawn*
content: Did we really need this movie? Or is Hollywood that desperate for money grabbing? The movie is all over the place. It starts off slow, keeps going slow, and ends even slower. Is it a documentary? No. Is it a drama? Not quite. Is it a... what is it exactly? Who knows. Probably not even the director.The "plot" was known due to the 50 previous documentaries (all of which were more entertaining) and movies about this tragedy, this brought nothing new whatsoever; except big names in an attempt to seduce you.Adding dramatic music to boring dialog and drama-less scenes does not create drama. This movie uses this technique throughout. You think something will happen due to the music, but then like a bad horror movie, nothing does happen.Verdict: Cue dramatic music and bury it under an avalanche.

title: the mount everest expedition
content: Review: I really enjoyed this movie because it shows you what people are willing to do for publicity. The direction and screenplay are quite good. The casting and acting are good also. All in all I would give this four out of a possible five stars.

title: Good
content: I watched this movie on an 11 hour plane ride to kill some time. I don't really remember what happened during the film. But it made me fall asleep so A+ for that.

title: Good Altitude but not the Summit
content: The consensus seems to be this is a solid movie that does not quite attain greatness, and this is reflected in its score. People who know a thing or two about mountaineering give it their praise and reservations, whilst those who know nothing and are passionless in their lives tend to be the ones to give it hate. I incline towards the former, since being a mountaineer myself I can identify with the drive and love of Earth's wild places that can make folk want to risk their lives on the ultimate, but I'd be a touch more generous in my mark: an '8'.That's because the movie itself is extremely well made, well acted and realistic in its depiction of a big snowy mountain and its perils, not to mention the administration and logistics involved in an expedition to this one. It is what it is: a detailed and accurate dramatisation of the real-life disaster of 1996 up there. It's almost too realistic, and actually portrays the mentality of those characters with an uncomfortable honesty, although never overtly taking one side or another. The facts are left, very cleverly and responsibly, to speak for themselves and incur public opinion of those who care to weigh it up beyond their own prejudice or personal interest.My enduring reaction is gosh, that Doug Hansen fella (John Hawkes) basically got his guide Rob Hall (Jason Clarke) killed, didn't he? Along with himself. Whether this was exactly as it happened, only they could know, but it looked very credible as the childish obsession of the amateur mountaineer to add his name to the droves who have now summited 'tourist Everest' played out its consequences, as he would simply not turn back when advised to and Hall was too kind to insist. The part that really made me angry, though, was the wife of Beck Weathers (Josh Brolin's character) basically blackmailing the rescue services to get a helicopter out there to him, at huge risk to the pilots' lives.Said unselfish pilots are the only folk who came off truly heroically well in this movie. As to the rest, it really made me take stock of my own ambitions, which are risky enough (eg Scottish mountains solo in winter). I once wanted to do Everest (using up my life savings and hard earned inheritance of my late parents), but what the hell would it mean anyway when you've basically been 'hand-held' (as Jake Gyllenhaal's character put it) as one of a neverending stream of nobodies or B-list celebrities? I do not want to attempt anything that I can't get up and down off my own resources, thanks, and I'd only feel I deserve rescue if I was extremely unlucky having been competent and working within my limitations. By the way, you get more solitary wilderness experiences around Scotland than you'd ever get on Everest these days.

title: Excellent Movie About How Fragile (And Futile) Life Can Be
content:
This is an awesome film, so severe, so dooming, so palpable, so menacing. And it sends one and a very clear message - the Nature is too tough to trifle with, it is too violent, too wild, too unpredictable, too huge for us to fathem. This enormity of the Everest Mount, this unbelievably awesome scale, this tremendous size, this humongous altitude diminishes all people and makes them look like tiny tots.
This is a very deep, a bit slow one, but deeply tragic, deeply serious, grave and solemn. It sends chills, it sends vibes, it sends a clear warning - don't mess with Mount. It sawllows people easily. 
I was very freightened after watching this movie, as it is so brutally honest, so horribly shocking, The very sheer volume of the Everest just opnes eyes and shows how unnecessary it is to climb there and die there.

title: Great movie with some good cinematography
content: Certainly! Here's an expanded version of your paragraph:I have no complaints about the movie; in fact, I think it was directed exceptionally well, capturing the essence of the story and the emotions of the characters. However, my focus here will be on a tragic event that unfolded during the descent, which led to the loss of five lives that day. 🤔 It's a heartbreaking situation to reflect on, and I can't help but think that if Rob had made a different decision and not allowed Doug to go further during the ascent, it might have changed the outcome significantly. This choice could have potentially saved a few lives that day.The consequences of Doug's determination were profound. Because of his insistence, both Rob and Harold found themselves trapped at the summit, unable to descend safely. I often wonder what might have happened if Rob had strictly adhered to his protocols and insisted that Doug turn back when the conditions became risky. Had he taken that decisive action, they could have made their way down in time to assist Beck and the woman who were also in peril. It's a painful reminder of how critical decision-making can be in high-stakes situations, and how one choice can ripple out and affect many lives.

title: The summit is not just a goal, it's the peak of dedication
content: Everest is a film about various climbers from different backgrounds, who each has their own motives to reach the top. Many of those climbers are amateurs facing the inhuman environment of Everest with the help of professional guides. The guides help them reach the top but their primary job is to get them home safe. That proves very difficult when a ravaging storm hits the mountain when most of the climbers are taking their final steps towards the summit.What do people do in situations of life and death? Do you risk your life to safe others or will you safe your own skin? Everest is a magnificent story about real humans battling forces of nature, more than 8 km above sea level. What you get is a breathtaking experience where you follow each character so closely, you merge into their lives for 2 hours.Baltasar Kormákur is starting to make a name for himself as a director. This is the first film he really gets to show what he is made of. Everest is the kind of film where every aspect needs to be carefully thought of in order for the film to be enjoyable. Baltasar Kormákur did an excellent job by creating this masterpiece.Baltasar is the first great Icelandic director. Being Icelandic myself I was really looking forward to see this film. I knew it had received good criticism and I had therefore very high expectations. I can safely say that this film exceeded those expectations.All in all, I think this film delivered the story perfectly. You feel as if you are a part of the expedition. You not only feel the characters' struggle, you take part in it with them. A great film I would recommend to everyone.

title: A Great Hollywood Movie Disaster
content:
No, that's not an error of syntax, 'Movie Disaster' is an entirely fitting epithet for the two hours of bland clichéd drivel that I just subjected myself to.Synopsis:
A group of wealthy, entitled, and in some cases entirely unfit people need to bolster their fragile egos.
In order to do this, they travel to a third world country to climb to the top of the world biggest rock because ... 'reasons'.
The big rock isn't that cool with they idea of having silly little people clambering all over it and leaving their s##t everywhere, so with the help of his friends snow, wind, and ice decides to show them whose boss.Surprisingly ... big rock wins!In Short:
Insipid dialogue.
Stereotypical Hollywoodian characters.
Zero character development.
Obligatory nausea inducing soppy bits.
Total lack of info about why certain key failures happened (read the books).
... and why should we give a damn about these idiots anyway?Save your time and watch something decent, such as Touching The Void.

title: Very cool
content: Very cool movie that I enjoyed. It was very accurate to the irl roblox everest game. Btw my rob username is @hugh_jnuz so add me for free robuxl. ANyway, the movie was very suspense and I got shivers all the time of fear. All of my friends are now mountain cimbing enthusiasts after watching the movie and playing the roblox game. Overall i would say you should watch this movei, but be warned it is very spooky. Also the book is pretty good probably. Idk never actually read it. Fun fact: everest is a continent continent convergence boundary. It is made of metamorphic grantetic rock. Fun fact:George Washington was born at Pope's Creek in 1732. ..

title: Overall movie I'd say 3 1/2, but it is based on one of the most tragic real life events ever put on film.
content: The emotional impact throughout the film didn't feel too strong to me, but the ending before the credits was quite an emotional scene itself even without a moving picture. If you don't really know about the event that occurred, much of it as well as the film was pretty unpredictable as large groups of people in 1996 take on the most daring challenge mother nature has to offer. I don't know if much of the movie or the whole movie was filmed in Everest, but if so, a really big kudos to that. Really big kudos. Either way, this was a pretty incredible film involving love, daringness, courage, hope, and a pretty good emphasis on cooperation.

title: Exploitative, unfocused; it should have been a documentary
content: A bit traumatised for a moment afterward. Rather exploitative, filming it in gimmicky 3D. It made the cinematography of the mountains even more impressive, but during dramatic moments, it seemed out of place (plus, it seemed distracting just to be wearing those silly glasses during those scenes) .The immense, massive scale and impact of the mountain itself clashed with what was the smaller scale horror the hikers were enduring. I wasn't expecting some generic action movie, but it really seemed like those two elements worked against each other.Effectively horrifying scenes of the approaching storm itself, completely enveloping the mountain and unfortunate climbers, and of hikers almost casually tumbling over the mountainside. Good acting all around, but also an unfocused narrative; an All-star cast with no central character. Almost everyone seemed to have only an extended cameo appearance, but nothing more.Parts of it I enjoyed, probably couldn't watch it a second time, though.

title: I can't add anything to what has been said except...
content: I didn't read IMDb.com carefully (shameless plug) and thought Everest was going to be a documentary. I was pleasantly surprised to find that it was more of a docudrama based on real events.I often choose which movies to view based on the appropriateness of the language used, with the rationale that if I don't speak that way and no one in my home should, why should I pay for the same? I can think of dozens of other films I've seen that were ruined by inserting swear words where they seemed out of place. I applaud the movie Everest for being an intense adventure movie that used virtually no objectionable language--at least that I can remember. The lack of offensive language was incredibly refreshing.The footage and drama were in this movie were riveting. I marveled that when the climbers were having such a hard time in some scenes shot from above, how the photographers were able to record such shots. They must have been staged on other mountains, but they looked realistic to me.

title: A Breathtaking but Perplexing Journey
content: Watched Everest on a lazy Sunday, not expecting much, but wow-this one really pulled me in. The cast alone was a pleasant surprise-so many familiar faces, from Jason Clarke and Josh Brolin to Jake Gyllenhaal and Keira Knightley. A truly stacked lineup.The film itself is visually stunning, capturing the sheer brutality and beauty of Everest in a way that makes you feel the altitude sickness creeping in. It's intense, emotional, and at times downright harrowing. You really feel the danger, the cold, and the sheer madness of what these climbers put themselves through.But by the end, I was left with one burning question: Why? Why do these people risk everything-their families, their lives-to conquer this mountain? The movie gives some answers, but none that fully satisfy. Maybe that's the point. Maybe Everest is something that can only be understood by those who feel the pull.Either way, Everest is a gripping survival drama that's worth the watch. It may not answer all your questions, but it'll definitely leave you thinking.

title: disappointing
content: I was hoping for an exciting action adventure movie, but it's just a boring drama.

title: Good Man vs Nature Film
content: EVEREST tells the true story of a group of climbers trapped on Mt Everest during a severe weather event. I had heard the story before and seen interviews with those involved, and I always found it intriguing. The trailer for this one looked good but I was a little worried that the filmmakers would ruin it. They got a big famous cast and a big budget, so it only seemed natural to me that they would over dramatize things and give it the real Hollywood treatment, which tends to make things worse.But that was not the case here, fortunately. The film was stunningly shot and the story and acting were great. I was on the edge of my seat the whole time, the climax was true to life, and I think this may have been Jake Gyllenhaal's best performance yet. Surely it is. No doubt about it. Recommend.

title: 2015's most gripping action thriller.
content: This movie took my breath away as the director takes the most challenging role of showcasing Mt. Everest with mortal men and women at the mercy of it. If you for one second forget about the CGI's used, you actually get immersed into the Realness of the movie. None of the actors have been glorified to an extent of irritation of the viewer. Actors are believable and so are their emotions. Some reviewers have unfairly compared this mountain thriller to Gravity which is sickening. I would say filming this movie is more challenging than filming the Gravity as the latter involves handful of lead actors and here a dozen or more folks stranded in an icy mountain with realistic surroundings. some of the scenes taken aerial like the climbers passing through wooden bridge or the edge of everest are truly breathtaking !!. i wish the movie would have ended in a positive note but as this movie is based on 1996 true events, we have to take in the sad climax.. it looks like Americans love to watch their beloved American super-flicks involving comics and their history and obviously ignore these little gems..(proof is the box office collections of US). I wish this movie grossed 500 m and above.. Coming to acting department Jason Clarke, Emily Watson, Keira Knightley and Robin shine. Jake Gyllenhaal has been weirdly casted with some curious clothes and peculiar grin..doesn't create an impact like Jason. Josh Brolin gives another exaggerated irritating acting but believable to the role. The only suggestion to the director is to shoot some twisting and thrilling climactic scenes to make the movie standout as some of the more famous directors do.

title: Awesome movie 🎥
content: Watching movies like this shows how much we are charged in front of nature.

title: Just like the mountain, this will kill you
content: As i was watching Everest i had a strange feeling i was about to share the fate of some of the characters in this movie, that i wouldn't make it. And sure enough my journey up Everest lasted roughly 80 mins. I understood that this mountain movie was not going to be in the same vein as flicks like Cliffhanger or Vertical Limit, so i was quite interested in this movie as i thought it would be a deep driven character narrative story not some lame absolute soul sucking dreck of a movie. From the get go this flick had no hope as the actors involved were lumped in to performing some of the most laughable dialogue i have heard in any movie for a long time and once they finally decided to leave one of the 3000 base camps they continuously traveled between and begin the ascent up Everest it turned in to an even more hilarious clichéd piece of crap. The only saving grace for this movie is the drop dead gorgeous camera work that captures the beauty of such a harsh environment, but i'm sorry i need a bit more in a movie then just that. I must note as well due to the quality of actors i thought that at least the individual performances would bring something to the table,but i was wrong. I have seen better acting from extras in porno movies so this would have to go in the back of the resume of every involved. Overall just a horrible experience and one i hope anyone who reads this review will avoid.

title: Harrowing Film
content: This is a film based on the true story of then1996 disaster on Mt Everest. The scene at the end with Rob Hall talking to his wife is harrowing. It really shows what a combination of summit fever and bad weather can do.

title: Glad I was able to see
content: I wasn't aware of this movie release, but recently watched it. This concerns an event I wasn't totally aware of--the 1996 disaster on Mt. Everest. The movie focuses on the groups that were guided up the world's tallest mountain and the tragedy that followed. The movie is done well with good performances. A lot of big name actors.The one complaint I'd have about the movie was there was a little more build up that could have been removed to tell more of the disaster part of the story where 12 people ended up dying. The movie is told simplistically and probably very close to how the people who have behaved and how events would have unfolded. Nothing overly dramatic, but a story worth telling.8/10

title: Intesting film
content: "Inspired by the extraordinary events occurring when trying to get on top of the highest mountain in the world , Everest is the true story of two different expeditions that have forced the participants to test their limits at extreme when they were surprised by one of the worst storms in recorded history of mankind. Mountaineers have faced obstacles to impossible , and their passion and obsession of a lifetime - to conquer that peak - has become a battle against time for survival". An extended version of what appears in the film. I mean, what I get from the people I love , obviously , is a response very visceral , powerful movie and so I felt when I read his version of John Krakauer of this story and then I read more afterwards. But I remember that I reacted very visceral to this story , and then, when I was asked to do, I called a friend of mine , Dean Poulter , who died a few months ago and It was a pillar of the community climbing , and I said " Hey , what do you think that 'll make this movie ? 'and he said something like , " Absolutely , do it ! And then cleans Everest when you do it ... " He then began to make plans for me , how to do the movie . But the experience became very visceral for us. It was a collective experience . I hated them and I loved these guys and I would not give up any hour of experience .. I recommend this film Everest,it is my favorite.

title: Borrring as heck
content: One of the most boring movies ever. Can't believe how a story as compelling could be pulled off so poorly. Had to just quit halfway through.1 out of 10.

title: Exciting despite defects
content: Films about adventures in extreme conditions like space, underwater, desert are already evoking expectations as we are ready to buy whatever we are served. This is definitely one of them. The scenery is great, I wonder how much of it belongs to real Everest. The pace of the film is regular and gets into the subject without boring romantic stories. Some shortcomings, however, do exist concerning technical issues. For example, in most of the movie the mountaineers were wearing ordinary sunglasses or nothing at all to protect their eyes. I was expecting that they wore goggles and balaclava at all times. They might have been purposefully removed so that we could distinguish the characters. Whatever, it is easy to criticize this way. Other than this, in my opinion the ordeal of surviving in extreme conditions could have been augmented even further. Despite all these, it is rewatchable and deserves an 8/10.

title: Excellent Movie
content: Watched this movie recently in TV. Its really good. Movie really replicated the accident. Cinematography looks very natural. Its make us to feel in Himalayas.

title: Breath- Taking yet Heart Breaking
content: When I first saw the trailer of this movie, I had doubts whether this movie will live up to my expectations or not.But then I finally decided to give it a try. Thank god I gave it try.What a movie!!! What a realistic movie. It is too real to be called a movie.The Camera-work, Visuals are breath-taking, gut- wrecking yet overwhelming.Everything is great about this movie.One needs pure skill, courage and sheer will to even try for such a dangerous expedition. BUt sometimes skills and courage are not enough to survive, sometimes one is helpless in front of nature.I would like to congratulate the Director for Directing the Movie so beautifully(and being so technically sound).This movie is for the people who likes adventure and are brave heart, not for fragile hearted.I give this 10/10 , Really its that Good.

title: Anti Climatic, could of been much better then it was
content: i was actually really looking forward to this movie, the premise seemed good, and the cast of actors seemed like a sure hit on paper, the finished product isn't so great which can be blamed on the films rating (pg) being constructing for what they could of done with it while the cinematography is breathtaking, and the actors mostly on point, what we get is a slow moving film, that really feels more a glorified reenactment of the what happens, then a Hollywood film. Everest moves at a sluggish pace all the way to end, while being predictable and bland throughout this film really struggles to know what it is, as it tentatively makes moves to be dramatic, slightly thriller with jump scares and nothing else much.I must say keeping track of the characters is rather hard as unless you see there faces, you mainly cant keep track of who is where, as they all were similar clothes, but credit is needed for trying to give back story to everyone in the main story, but you really don't form any emotional connection with any of the characters I cant stress how much this film could of either been an intense thriller or a serious drama and it would of been a hit instead your just waiting for this big tense climatic moment to come that never does, and suddenly after one scene more, it just end making it feel anticlimactic Hence the 5/10 RATING

title: Wonderful, Elegant, Moving and Beautiful..
content: I was very excited for this movie. I watched it last night and I really loved it. It is an excellent movie. Baltasar Kormákur (Director) has successfully conveyed the emotions subtly and with respect for the true heroes of the expedition of 1996. His film perfectly demonstrates how Mount Everest is an extremely dangerous place for human beings.As it is based on a TRUE STORY, it makes you think about the characters, how they suffered, how this affected their lives, their families and so on. It shows the fighting resolve of human beings. This movie was a breathtaking and heart touching experience and almost made me cry.It had great casting, engaging cinematography and powerful sound. They made the right choice in characters and the focus was on right people. Jason Clarke and Josh Brolin were amazing in their roles. Visual effects were most impressing and the fact the some of the scenes were actually shot on Mount Everest makes it even great.I think everyone should go see this movie. It was truly a moving picture. In the end, RIP to people who died on Mount Everest in 1996.

title: Visually Stunning & Gripping Adventure
content: Everest takes us on quite the adventure up the world's highest and most famous mountain. But this isn't just any Mt. Everest experience. This movie tells the heartbreaking true story about the 1996 Mount Everest disaster. Many of those a part of this particular climbing excursion would not make it back off the mountain. There is something so alluring about climbing this mountain that many are willing to risk life and limbs for the experience. I will instead appreciate this undertaking from a distance by taking in the stories of the brave men and women who have been able to, or at least attempt to, summit this frozen giant. The climbing process of Everest is indeed fascinating. I was completely drawn in with these climbers as they struggled their way to the top. I feel like this movie gives the viewers a good idea of what it would be like to take on this dangerous adventure. In that way, and in many other ways, this movie is very successful. I was at the edge of my seat from the beginning because I knew what was ahead for these adventurers. The real life people of this story are portrayed by the familiar faces of a fantastic cast. This movie will surely have you wanting to do more research into this Everest tragedy. I highly recommend the book, "Into Thin Air" by Jon Krakauer. He is a survivor of this expedition. This will really help you get acquainted with everyone who was involved. Two tips I will give you for watching this movie; Get to know the characters a bit and pay attention to the coats they are wearing. When the storm hits, bodies and faces are completely covered at times and I started losing track of who was who in the blizzard. The true story behind the movie is riveting, and the movie does a fantastic job recreating it.

title: So well made!
content: I wish I could have seen this on the big screen! This was an impressively made film.When you know the story so well through all the books and the reports, it's hard not to critique the film through that lens. As a film it's limited because it shows the collective story through the perspective of an observer.So the nitty-gritty that is the individual stories of the survivors, and the dead, not explicitly told. But that doesn't take away the effects of the acting, and the special effects of the weather, and the turn of events. These are real people, with real lives, real families, who had goals.They all intersected together at a point in time that cost some their lives.Many actors I already liked, some of them I can't stand, but regardless, everybody's performance was excellent! They all worked so well together.

title: Amazing story telling & great acting!
content: I absolutely loved this movie!! I was a bit circumspect after reading some negative comments. After finishing the movie, I was thinking these people need to be banned. The direction, cinematography and acting were all top class. Best thing I loved about it was that I felt like I knew every character, I was feeling what they were going through! Goes to show how the characters were represented and the story telling. Jason Clarke was the highlight of the movie, he was great in every scene. Only disappointment for me was the lack of use of Jake Gyllenhaal, thought he could have been given more screen space. Josh Brolin and all other actors did a good job too. I highly recommended this movie if you like this genre!

title: This is a disaster movie
content: I'm really disappointed with reviews on IMDb it is suppose to be a page where people can make a decision on watching a movie or not, especially when these days an IMAX ticket cost almost 20 bucks, based on early review I went to watch this movie and here is my review. The best part in the movie was the trailers in the beginning, really!!! OK let me at least try to give this movie a somewhat favored review, first 15 minutes were engaging because the director shows parts of Nepal and how that part of the world is different than western world. The star- cast of this movie is the biggest bait for movie goers, assuming so many good actors the movie has to be good, it has to have some screenplay, some thrill, some comedy and there was None! Those who are interested in the story it would be enough to read the wikipedia page about the real disaster this movie isn't worth a DVD view.And please people leave a fair review and fair ratings of the movies, otherwise the whole purpose of this website is zero.

title: This is a DRAMA movie not an ACTION movie, people!
content: A lot of the reviewers here who have voted low on this movie were expecting an ACTION movie. Well, sorry folks. Go and watch some trashy JJ Abrams or Michael Bay rubbish if you want that. This movie is actually a DRAMA. Why is it a drama? Because it is based on TRUE EVENTS. And that is where it leaves ACTION and gets into DOCUMENTARY. And this is where this movie SUCCEEDS.It does not go all "Hollywood" on the script and add in "action" scenes to appease the popcorn eating morons that can't comprehend anything more than flashing lights, bangs and sirens. It does not even have a "good guy" and a "bad guy." It has to be ACCURATE otherwise it can only claim to be "based on true events" instead of being "a true story." So shut up idiots who said this movie was "boring" or "had no action" etc etc etc. YOU people are boring and your attention spans are that of children.Having said that, the movie is well made. There are big names in it. The only thing that annoyed me slightly is that lead character is played by an Australian and makes absolutely ZERO effort at sounding like a New Zealander which he is supposed to be. It makes me wonder if that was intentional. Imagine this: some "true-blue" New Zealander in the main role would lose most of the audience with his unintelligible accent, due to their horrendous treatment of vowels, "the ear is thoon ... and the weether is bed." (This is the very reason New Zealanders can't be understood by the rest of the English-speaking world.) SO, I get it. At least Australian vowels are more in keeping with the rest of the world. On the other hand Keira Knightly and Emily Watson's New Zealand accents were almost dead on - as busted as that accent is. Good effort, ladies. I cringed in all the right places.The story was well executed. The ending was quite touching. Knowing that this is an unembellished telling of true events it makes it even more emotional.My hat goes off to this great mountaineer and New Zealander (sorry, won't fall into that kitschy, cutesy thing of calling a New Zealander a "Kiwi.")

title: Probably the most accurate but least compelling account
content: The best audience for this movie may be people not familiar with the various and varying accounts of the 1996 expeditions. But the cinematography gives you a true feel of the riskiness of the environment: knife edge cornices, 2 foot trails with 5,000 foot drops, the seemingly endless ascent.Having read most of those aforementioned accounts, the movie makes only brief exposition of the debated critical errors. Some are totally ignored. I was much more emotional reading the accounts. Feeling the gut-wrenching nature of the life and death decision made when an ascent or descent goes wrong. I didn't get that feeling with this movie.But if you don't want to get into a debate over who made the most mistakes (Boukreev vs. Hall. vs. Fischer vs. Ang Dorje, etc.), it's a very good accounting of the events from the perspective of the Adventure Consultants' camp.

title: High-grade film
content: I give films a vote of above 7-8 really seldom and let me begin with explaining how I rate them. At the beginning I consider the film to be perfect with 10 points. But in process of watching film I deduct point by point for some minor aspects. Most common minor aspects are stupid dialogs, stupid acting, weak places of plot, absolutely unrealistic moments. That tally 7-8 point for the greatest films of nowadays. Getting down to our film, I had almost no reason to deduct any of points for the above-mentioned minors. Everything in film is nearly perfect. The film begins with absolutely outstanding shots of the Himalayas. Every technical part of film (sound, picture, editing) is perfect. In such kind of films it is more than important to have a viewer deep in the atmosphere. The plot was written very carefully, due to the multiple sources, such as books of the participants of the notorious climbing, which took place on Everest mount in 1996, documentary film (1998) and true facts. I can't imagine plot to be any better, because it is always hard to adopt true story for a film, especially with a genre like this. But there are still a few shots, I consider shouldn't have taken place in this film. That goes to "not perfect plot" and the reason of vote 9 out of 10. At the same time film is not overextended, I would even say it is rather brief, keeping you near the screen all the time.I will not tell much about acting, it is just very impressive. And there is not unrealistic exaggerations in the film. It also contains some moral about a lot of things, shown in small dozes. The movie is very colorful and simply beautiful, you can enjoy Himalayas all through the film. I watched it in 2D and can assure you, it looks much better this way, don't bother yourself with 3D version!

title: A movie worth watching....
content: A good, solid introduction into the world of climbing Mt. Everest, the characters that would do such a crazy thing , and the peculiarities and dangers they face when climbing to the highest point on the globe. The movie isn't a deep-dive into the psychology/morality/selfishness of the people involved in the dangerous activity of climbing Everest, and there are many questions to be asked, but it's a story of the tragedy that occurred in 1996 and the perfect storm of variables that led to it. Simply put, it's more of a story about how it happened, rather than why. And to that end it works well. The cinematography is beautiful and you get a feel for the mountain, the acting is top notch, and the story and settings are easy to comprehend. Even if you already knew of this event, the movie is still compelling.There are many good books written about this disaster, and of course there are differing accounts of it, but reading Jon Krakauer's and Boukreev's accounts are probably the best way to go and then decide for yourself. Both raise compelling points written, and the books reveal a few, very interesting aspects of this story that were left out of the movie.But overall, a very good movie.

title: Top of the world, Ma!
content: Docudrama climbs new heights - in fact, to the summit of the world's highest mountain - in this adrenaline-intensive re-creation of the tragic climbing season of May 1996 when eight people died in a two-day blizzard on Everest. Although there are big-name stars here (Jake Gyllenhaal, Sam Worthington, Keira Knightley), no one is allowed to grandstand: what counts is the ascent. The script gives us glimpses of the climbers' everyday lives - the wives holding their breath at home - and the support team at the various Camps; and, never forget, the Sherpas. But the movie's biggest star is the mountain - and, it must be said, the cameramen who surely took serious risks to obtain the footage.The CGI people have seamlessly joined scenes shot in the Italian Alps to the Everest shoot. You totally feel (especially if you see it in 3D and IMAX) that you are up there with these people crawling across bottomless crevasses and dizzying slopes. You also get a sense of what drives these mountaineers, a force somewhere between bravery and foolhardiness, to take on one of the greatest challenges our planet has to offer.

title: Jon Krakauer
content: How can this movie paint this man as a coward?The idea that being a hero at that altitude and not suffer your own death is just insane,

title: Riveting
content: OK, I didn't see the IMAX version, but now I think I would like to. I was a nervous wreck from the moment the movie started, being familiar with the story (Into Thin Air), but this was so more about the MOUNTAIN.The acting is excellent and although the film does not delve much into the characters' personal lives, it is clear from the start that "Everest" is in charge--no one "coquers Everest. There is compromise, sacrifice, and sometimes the ultimate sacrifice. I will never understand the need to climb this peak, but I respect those who try and those who make it possible.I would have liked to see a little more about the Sherpas, and maybe even the politics and environmental impact the hundreds of climbers have had on the mountain. But all in all, this is an epic movie. It was fascinating to read (on another site) about the filming.I will never make it to Everest, so this film is as close as I will come--and it is spectacular and deserving of all the respect it deserves--the movie and the MOUNTAIN.

title: "Everest" to inspire you to climb your own mountain
content: Snow flurries pierce your face as you lie on the frigid snow. Your hands and feet are frozen solid along with the oxygen tank at your side. As your body starts succumbing to frostbite, you remember that you are not 26,000 feet in the air on the slopes of the tallest mountain in the world. You're in a movie theater, the air conditioning is turned up a bit and you're almost out of popcorn."Everest" is a visual and emotional roller coaster that retells the fight for survival of several climbers during the 1996 Mount Everest tragedy. The story follows two expeditions, one led by Rob Hall (Jason Clarke) and the other by Scott Fischer (Jake Gyllenhaal), and the storm that took the lives of five climbers from the two teams.Rob is a kind-hearted, sympathetic guide who helps pioneer the idea of giving amateur climbers the opportunity of a lifetime. Scott is more carefree and rebellious. His philosophy is that if you can't make it up the mountain by yourself, you shouldn't be on the mountain at all.The film's performances are one of its shining qualities. While no one stands out, Clarke, Gyllenhaal, Josh Brolin, Keira Knightly, Sam Worthington, John Hawkes and the rest of the cast deliver several tear-jerking scenes in the movie's two hour run time. The portrayals make you care about the characters. You root for Rob and his team because of Clarke's embodiment of a good man, wanting to get home to his wife (Knightly) and his soon to be born child.While the characters themselves are played superbly, there's very little development of these characters, and they are placed in an uninteresting story. The movie plays out exactly how you think it will. Tragedy strikes and people die. There's nothing in the narrative that sets it apart from disaster movies that have come before it, and thankfully the story was not the focal point of "Everest.""Human beings simply aren't built to function at the cruising altitudes of a seven-forty-seven," Rob tells his team at the beginning of the film, and it's not until they reach what is called the "death zone" that his statement begins to sink in.The tension builds as the air thins, and each crunch of a footstep has you antsy for a potential avalanche, and for the perfect storm you know is coming. Baltasar Kormakur's direction and Salvatore Totino's cinematography envelop you in the icy drama, elevating the experience of the movie and overshadowing its bland narrative.Over 200 bodies lay frozen on Mount Everest's slopes today that serve as a reminder for climbers of the price they may pay when pursuing such a feat. For most that set out to reach the summit however, the risk is worth the reward, and the reward comes in various shapes and sizes.It's the final destination for professional climbers, the pièce de résistance of their careers. For others like "Everest's" Doug Hansen, the reward is found in following one's dreams and inspiring others in the process.You don't have to climb a mountain to stand on top of the world. Whether it's starting your own business, writing a novel or becoming a professional athlete, we all have big dreams and should go the distance to make those dreams a reality. Brian Blessed said it best, "You can't call it an adventure unless it's tinged with danger. The greatest danger in life, though, is not taking the adventure at all. To have the objective of a life of ease is death. I think we've all got to go after our own Everest."

title: yet another example of over-exaggerated Western Heroism
content: Who put those ropes in? Who put the ladders across the ice-fall? Who put up those tents they're climbing into? Who carried the oxygen? Who carried the food they're now eating? The Sherpas do that work and that is never shown. The Sherpas did a huge amount of work on this expedition and they were heavily involved in the rescue. There were also Sherpas killed so I think it's yet another example of them being left out of the story, yet another example of over-exaggerated Western Heroism.

title: Everest (2015) - Review
content: Everest tells the story of Kiwi mountaineer and guide Rob Hall and the terrible events that happened in 1996 while a large group was attempting to reach the summit of Mt. Everest. Being a true story you can usual expect bad things to happen and this is true, this film is brutal to watch at times, it's also very good. Director Baltasar Kormákur is probably best known lately for the 2013 film 2 Guns, staring Mark Wahlberg and Denzel Washington and while I quite enjoyed that film this is much better. I went into this film not knowing the details of the actual event it was based on and if you are the same I advise you to not look it up before you see the film.Before I knew this was based on a true story I had seen some trailers and thought that this was gonna be your typical stuck on a mountain disaster movie, it's really not at all. The film takes plenty of time to set up both the characters and the situation. It's actually quite educational, goes into great detail about how one goes about climbing the highest mountain in the world but it's never boring as it does this, it also does a solid job of making you never want to attempt this yourself.For really the first hour of the film we get to know all the main characters and we are with them as the go through their training. That training involved going up Everest and acclimatizing at a camp and then back down, the next time you go to the next camp up and so on until you have worked your way up to the summit. Some really bad weather happens and it hits the fan, that's all I'll say on that.This film really has a great cast, Jason Clarke plays Rob Hall and unfortunately he was one of my primary issues with the film, I like him fine but I really don't like him as a leading man, he did alright but I think someone else could have been better in the role. I found myself latching on to Josh Brolin the most, I felt that he gave the best performance in the film, really liked him. Sam Worthington was really good even though his role was fairly limited, Jake Gyllenhaal was fantastic as always and Keira Knightly gave a really strong performance even if her accent was a bit dodgy in places.The film looked fantastic, the cinematography was beautiful and there were a lot of moments where you will feel very cold just watching it. Unfortunately there were some moments that had some pretty obvious green screen and some bits that really looked like they were on a set, these were minor annoyances but they pulled me out of the film a little.Really well done telling of Rob Hall's story, great performances over all except for Jason Clarke and some minor visual issues, still highly recommend checking this out, preferably on IMAX.

title: Mind blowing movie, EPIC TRUE STORY
content: Great work , but not for impatience people, Yeat could be boring but intriguing. Submitting this review you are agreeing to the terms laid out in our Copyright Statement. Your submission must be your own original work. Your review will normally be posted on the site within 2-3 business days. Reviews that do not meet the guidelines will not be posted. Please write in English only. HTML or boards mark-up is not supported though paragraph breaks will be inserted if you leave a blank line between paragraph. Your submission must be your own original work. Your review will normally be posted on the site within 2-3 business days. Reviews that do not meet the guidelines will not be posted. Please write in English only. HTML or boards mark-up is not supported though paragraph breaks will be inserted if you leave a blank line between paragraph.

title: Let's use artistic license as an excuse to completely falsify the event
content:
Really? Another movie about the 1996 Everest tragedy? Oh, and this time we will use artistic license to completely misrepresent characters, twist facts, deny real heroes their recognition and generally throw random crap at the audience. With the 15 second attention spans of today, it is disgusting that a segment of the population will be in awe of this banal worthless attempt. I was at the edge of my seat as the helicopter clipped the snow bank (yeah, not really, only complete idiots would have bought into that).
Next time, change the name of mountain, the characters and everything else and see if you can sell such an insulting script to people who actually have a 3 digit IQ.
Dr. Weathers could not have possibly given consent to this feeble attempt of mis-represented drama and tragedy where the man who risked his life to rescue him was not even mentioned by title or accurate portrayal.
The only reason for a couple of stars is that there are fleeting moments of scenery that remind me of the mountains and their majesty.

title: The Climax is Not the Summit
content: I recently watched this film to witness the tallest summit in the world. Everest stands 29,029 feet above sea level. This film is based on true events that took place on the May 1996 expedition. This has been a well know story that was depicted in the best- selling account of the expedition by Jon Krakauer's Into Thin Air.As the movie begins we see a few men traveling to Nepal that we learn to know as Beck, Doug, and Jon Krakauer. Soon after we are introduced to Rob Hall the guide for the team.I enjoy watching a movie that is based on true events first before reading about the films fact base. The reason being it adds to the natural emotions intended by the director. Since this story was not only published, but had taken place over 19years ago, it would be unwise to assume this story was already known. In my anticipation to watch this movie I read a review that explains the story line. Moreover, I came to find out this review had spoilers of the true events and read of 8 people dying on this mountain.Although, I had known 8 people died this day I was unaware of the popularity surrounding this day. May 10th has been the day Rob Hall had summited 4 years before. The film focuses on the clients of Rob Hall and their personal stories leading up the reason why they are all here to climb Everest. Rob was a well-known and respected guide to the summit due to his fame of summiting the most number of times. Others provided the nickname "Mountain Goat" or "Show" for Rob Hall. His date of climbing had also been known amongst the other guides as the day to summit. This is depicted in the movie and in each of the climbing books as one of the busiest days in each of the preceding years.This amount of traffic is one concern that is consistently discussed and highlighted on. There is a one-lane path to the summit known as the Hillary Step. This has been another bottleneck for climbers trying to summit since only a fixed number of climbers can be on the narrow pathway.Within the movie Rob Hall calls a meeting for the guides to discuss summiting on alternative days. These other guides were insulted to be told what day they can climb with their clients and the meeting was thereby ended.The film highlighted many facts about the mountain and the sickness that can come with the accent. Hall lays out the dangers of summiting Everest in his briefing to his team before they even set foot on the mountain. He explains, "Human beings are not designed to function at the cruising altitude of a 747. Your bodies will be literally dying." It is later found out that they individually paid a lot of money ($65,000 each) to get them to the top of Everest. Rob further discusses that the point is not to get to the top, but safely back down. The experience in my opinion made Everest seem as if you were told to wear a lead- suit and climb 200 steps in freezing temperatures. This is an annoyed, but understanding point of the events that took place. The movie focuses on the preparation of acclimatizing for a majority of the movie. Then some of the various teams are seen summiting after the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th camps cites. Unfortunately, this made the movie seem anticlimactic while at the summit. I was hopeful for more of an awe-inspiring scene or two leading up to the team's summit.Although, I felt that we were suddenly at the top of Everest there was more to this film. And if you knew the turn of events, you knew that the climax had only just begun. This film still managed to inspire me and teach a few ethical dilemmas we may face at some point in our lives.Works Cited:Everest. Dir. Baltasar Kormákur. Perf. Jason Clarke, Jake Gyllenhaal, Keira Knightley, Josh Brolin, Sam Worthington, Michael Kelly, John Hawkes and Emily Watson. 2015. Film.

title: Everest
content: At first glance, we can consider this film as yet another of those umpteenth adventure films, a bit like the end of the world 2012. But if that's what you want to see, turn around! This film is above all, in my opinion, based on a true story, a story of overcoming, a story of combat.Between breathtaking images (to be seen in 3D), excellent sound and an impeccable cast, Everest does not leave you indifferent. Nevertheless, the scenario is not unexpected, but this film, carried by this impressive cast, makes you think about existential questions about oneself, nature, and surpassing oneself.In short, I recommend this 3D film to have a good time, and to feel like you're on the highest point of Everest... 8/10.

title: Go and see it
content: Ever since I found out that there is going to be a movie about 1996 disaster, I was thrilled. I had just read "Into thin air" by J. Krakauer, one of the survivors, and I was so moved by it, that I wanted to learn something more. And when I read that this movie won't be entirely based on this book, I was even happier because it meant new perspective.I have to say - Jason Clarke was the perfect choice. I didn't know him before, I had seen only "Zero Dark Thirty", but that was it. At first I actually hoped, that Jake Gyllenhaal will have a bigger role, just because I knew what to expect from him. But Jason really shined as Rob and his and Keira's conversations touched me.It was beautifully filmed, the sound effects were fantastic, and, since I had read the book, I had almost no problem to identify the characters. The only thing that I wanted to change was that I wanted to know more about others as well. Rob was the only one I actually cared about, and I don't think that was only my problem - it's just that the others didn't capture my attention.Overall it was a beautiful movie, but I don't think that 3D is necessary.

title: The Summit of Mountain Movies
content: Never understood why this wasn't at the Oscars. Have seen this picture already four times and keeps me at the edge of my seat everytime.

title: Simply Stunning and deserving of all the awards coming its way
content: We watched this in the local IMAX in 3D. I am not normally a fan of 3D, but have to say that this movie made you realize just how effective 3D cinema can be if it is done well. I've read several of the books relating to this disaster on Everest, and was surprised how accurately the movie followed the books, which is a massive challenge as everyone's account of exactly what happens differs to some extent, and often markedly.As many other people have commented, the cinematography is nothing short of genius. There are some jaw-dropping shots that really demonstrate how huge Everest is, and what a ridiculous task it is to climb it. I don't think I've ever seen a film that managed to communicate perspective in such a way.Some of the reviewers have said that they were disappointed that the characters were not fleshed out more. I don't quite understand this as I felt the movie did an excellent job of introducing you to the key characters and providing enough back story to make concerned about whether they lived or died. To have fleshed out every character would have necessitated a mini series rather than a one-off movie as there were dozens of people involved.One huge testament to this film is that we were in a pretty full cinema and I don't recall one person getting up to go to the toilet or get refreshments. I can't ever recall any movie achieving that kind of effect.I'm struggling to try and think of any weaknesses in the film, but I honestly can't think of any. It is quite simply a cinematic triumph and deserves all the awards that are surely come its way.

title: Giveitarest
content: Apparently someone thought it would be a good idea to make a movie about entitled, privileged white people who think it is a good idea to litter the Earth's wildernesses with polyester, oxygen bottles, and their own dead bodies. At vast expense.Never mind that the only distinguishable character in the whole movie is Aussie /Kiwi Helen, the base camp co-ordinator (I think), whose job it is to express anxiety on the satellite phone when everybody else is wrapped up in garishly-coloured polyester in atrocious weather conditions. Up a mountain, in case you hadn't guessed.Completely overblown Euro-soundtrack, and ridiculous visual effects whose only effect is to indicate that the danger is a simulation: if you film a snow bridge from every angle possible it simply indicates that what you're filming is make-believe. And to call the people in this movie 'characters' is an insult to table football mannequins.Nothing heroic about this at all. Completely stupid, stupid, stupid. With Aussie OR Kiwi accents, which doesn't help.

title: Shows how this dangerous sport can easily become a life or death situation for all those involved
content: Everest is a drama film about the 1996 Mount Everest disaster which resulted in the deaths of several mountain climbers. Even though I know absolutely nothing about mountain climbing, nor do I have any interest in ever doing so myself, I really liked the film for the most part. It shows how this dangerous sport can easily become a life or death situation for all those involved.Since Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay first successfully reached the summit of Mount Everest in 1953, many other mountaineers have tried, and often failed to do so as well. One such mountaineer, a New Zealand man named Rob Hall (Jason Clarke), had managed to ascend to the top of Everest a record 4 times. This movie chronicles what would have been his fifth successful ascent to the top. Upon reaching the peak of the world's tallest mountain, Rob, along with the rest of his fellow mountaineers, are caught in a deadly snowstorm, which hinders the groups' progress in descending back to the bottom. Several members of Rob's group end up separated in the freezing cold snow with no other way to reach one another. Many frantic attempts at communicating with them via radio by the crew at the base camp offer them limited reassurance that most of the mountaineers will make it out of this expedition alive.I feel that this film's true story transitioned very well onto the big screen. The cinematography of Mount Everest was excellent and really made you feel as if you were right there with the mountaineers on top of the world's tallest mountain. Jason Clarke, in a role originally intended for Christian Bale, was great as Rob Hall and Keira Knightley was very good as well playing Rob's pregnant wife Jan. Josh Brolin shines too, playing an American doctor named Beck Weathers who wanted to climb to the top of the mountain with Rob's group. Even though this film solidified my determination that I will never go mountain climbing, I still very much enjoyed it.I rate it 8/10.

title: Everest As Intense As The Weather Surrounding The Mountain
content: Having read the book, I knew what to expect. However, seeing it unfold on a big screen, in 3D, made it even more chilling (no pun intended). First off, I will never, ever understand the people who willingly put themselves into, not only harm's way, but a terrifying, frigid, unforgiving harm's way such as this. The entire cast was more than up to the standards a movie like this demands. Harsh, heart-rending, and either exhilarating if you are into such self-inflicted misery, or puzzling and perplexing if you are like me, not seeing the need or necessity to scale a huge, unwelcoming, unpredictable piece of the planet such as Mount Everest. Make no mistake, this is not a happy, uplifting picture, but it is gripping and intense.

title: EVEREST 3D <> With breath taking visuals and a true insight to the power and beauty of Everest.
content: Director Baltasar Kormákur film based on the tragic true story of Rob Hall's (Jason Clarke) final climbing expedition to the highest point on Earth, Mount Everest. The New Zealand mountaineer joined forces with fellow climber, friend and competitor Scott Fischer (Jack Gyllenhaal) so their teams could summit the mountain during one of the most busiest seasons in the most safest possible way. During their mission they encounter the incredible force of nature leaving them to experience one of the most violent and catastrophic storms, turning Everest into a roaring beast where loved ones don't return.A British–American 3D disaster adventure/drama/thriller film written by Simon Beaufoy and William Nicholson. Josh Brolin (survivor Beck Weathers) digs his feet in and stands-out with a great realistic performance showing why is one of the main stars in Everest, with John Hawkes, Robin Wright, Michael Kelly, Sam Worthington, Keira Knightley (as Rob Scotts wife Jan Arnold), and Emily Watson also featuring. With breath taking visuals and a true insight to the power and beauty of Everest.

title: It's Like a Real Experience of Climbing Everest
content: Glorious at its name, the film is not a blockbuster with intense actions or CGIs, thanks to its original source from a true story in 1996, it works well as an adventurous hiking drama. The beginning is pretty surprising as it does not drag much and straight progressing to Nepal, followed by preparation for the climb and then most of the second half turns into a terrifying experience struggling to survive. At certain parts, there's some flaws of jumping scenes due to editing and it's quite confusing to track who is who due to too many characters but the cast has delivered promising performances and the stunning cinematography has brought audiences the great scenery of the peaks. The journey ends in an inspiring way that even though hiking is challenging, the psychology to deal with death and to face the reality are the hardest in life.

title: Everest: On the Edge
content: Another movie that I enjoyed is "Everest". I think it is a really good movie because it shows how hard it is to climb Mount Everest. It also shows how long a persons will to survive can take them, even though they were expected to die. The movie's lesson is that if you have the will power, you can do anything you want, such as climb Mount Everest. This movie was based off a true story about a group of climbers who wanted to get to the top, but sadly a storm hit before they made down the mountain. I give Everest a ten out of ten. Yayayayayayayyayaya yayayayayyayaya yayayayayayyaayayayayayayayayayayayayayay ayayayayayayayayayayayay ayayayayayayayayayayayaya yayayayayayayayayayayayaya

title: I absolutely loved this movie
content: Firstly before this movie I held mountains in no special regard at all, Secondly I was not really looking forward to the movie. I watched this movie with my girlfriend and was left spell bound by Mount Everest so much so I instantly went to research the 8000m peaks of the world as the film finished. Beautifully and brilliantly acted what more could you want from a movie. The power of Everest was amazingly captured by the cameraman and the exertion on the climbers was apparent in the actors too. One of the funny things is when the movie ended I found myself watching a documentary about the 1996 everest disaster and found the survivors to be just like the actors portraying them in the movie especially Beck weathers. I would highly recommend this movie to all.

title: A sobering experience about how determination is not enough
content: Everest wasn't the cinematic feast that I hoped it to be, but it was a gripping, miserable and extremely realistic experience of what that horrible climb in 1996.After many struggles, a commercial expedition led by Rob (Jason Clarke - extremely effective in the lead role) and Scott (Jake Gyllenhaal, who is excellent but completely underused) reach the top of Everest. It comprises ordinary joes and experienced climbers alike. The film does an excellent job at showing what a titan Everest is - what seems like a minor speed bump is actually the endgame for many climbers because it requires standing around in the debilitating cold. After defeating one such challenge, the team reaches the peak rather abruptly, and as a result the triumph is not particularly effective (maybe because it was shown in the trailer).The film's defining scene comes when Rob stops for Doug (John Hawkes), a climber who has failed at the threshold of the peak once and is struggling within eyeshot of it now. Rob tries to turn Doug back, but Doug pleads to push on, because he'll never do it again. Rob, in a moment of weakness, agrees. Kormakur's skilled direction and some nifty camera-work lulls the audience into a false sense of security. Go on, its right there! Its what, five hundred metres? Its clear out and he's so close! How long could it possibly take? He paid $65,000 for this! Everest's greatest and most sobering message is that determination is not only insufficient, but sometimes misplaced.On the descent, we see terrific visuals and great acting as the group of climbers struggle through storms and freeze. In one pivotal moment, a weak climber pleads that they have to leave their fallen companions or die with them. And such is the skill of the storytellers that I completely agreed with him.Baltasar Kormakur definitely knew what he's doing with the direction of Everest. The pacing was faultless, the movie never dragged on a single moment. The climb and the descent, the hope and the helplessness, are given equal weight, and the visual depiction of Everest is so realistic that it almost feels like we are there ourselves. Of a stellar cast, none have enough time to make an impact, but I'll make a special mention to Emily Watson, very emotional and likable as the Base Camp contact, and Sam Worthington, who proves he's actually a good actor, just not a lead actor.Everest is a sobering experience. I went in wanting to climb mountains one day. Now I just want to lie in bed with my electric blanket turned up to eleven and never leave electricity or gas heating again.

title: Irresponsible Adventurers
content: Anyone who thinks it is exciting to walk into a lions den deserves to get their head chewed off! Hiking up Everest is an Exhausting, Freezing, Mind Bending, Breath Taking, Selfish adventure that should be outlawed. The only thing saving this movie is the scenery and the acting. You know from the start that a bunch of hikers are going to die. In these circumstances, that is a certainty!! There is NOTHING fun about this experience!! There is only anxiety and fear on the part of the friends and family waiting below!!

title: What.A.Roller-coaster
content: This movie was extremely intense. The point was to convey what these particular people went through and how dramatic/ dangerous everything was.100% hit the nail on the head. I'm doing my best to not mention anything in particular but so many moments were leaving me on the edge of my seat and biting my nails.Small introduction story for the main character and the other characters had their small explanation as to why they were there but it's wasn't just about digging in to who they were, but more into what they did and went through.The depiction of how certain events happened was done so well you can't help but to squirm a little bit from the intensity.It ends up being quite the emotional roller-coaster and it a must to see it with a big TV and surround sound if you couldn't see it in the theater. Excellent movie.

title: If you love mountains or adventure, watch it.
content: Mountains share a one-sided relationship with mountaineers. They do not necessarily give the love back. Mountains behave to their will, live by its own and retain their self-composure indifferent to the time and living beings in its proximity. That is why climbers can reach the summit but not win the mountain. They never can. If a mountain is won, it no longer remains a mountain. It reduces to a pile of rocks.The film Everest understands well the fundamentally free nature of mountains. It could be because the film presents a real-life case that naturally observes this fact. But also because film makers made an effort to understand and accept it. Everest is not a tale of exaggerated heroism. Although the story has a lot of moments when characters could go out-of-the-way to save other troupe members, or demonstrate few acrobatics on snow. Fortunately, they do not. The film is also light on drama, saving some portion around the dying Rob.The 120 minute adventure-thriller keeps you on the edge of your seat with many breath taking shots of Great Himalayas. I will not include it however in any special camera-work as one only needs a helicopter to fly around for these shots. The aesthetics were ready made since 450 million years back when the Himalayas were born. Rather the real skills on camera are demonstrated in climbing shots framing the climbing trails in an absolutely inspirational manner. And the camera just fires up during the hail storm creating the needed velocity and ferociousness.A Climbing Scene Viewers would enjoy the Everest travelogue, looking at the response of families as they see-off their kin to most dangerous of expeditions, how people unite at the Everest base camp, how expedition is managed by professional staff, the churning climb-up, bewitching summit clash and the flustering walk back to the lower camps. The story is compact, and keeps a solid pace.
